What an awesome question, which I wish many more lyricists were asking. 1) Learn all the old formal esthetics of rhymed and metered poetry. You don’t have to follow those rules, at least not all the time, but they’ll surely help you get the effects you’re after. For example, listen to Nat King Cole’s “Walking My Baby Back Home” and notice that word-phrases line up with note-phrases (dum-diddy-dum, “Gee but it’s great”) and the use of internal rhymes, to give the whole thing the gait of two people walking home, half-dancing, not caring if they get there soon. Or Dylan’s “Don’t Think Twice, It’s All Right” with all those long vowels placed on a line that’s virtually on one pitch (“when your rooster crows at the break of dawn” — ooo oh ay awww) Old-style poetics is where you start paying attention to what the words sound like, and sound is the critical thing in lyrics. “Before this river becomes an ocean, Before I pick my heart up off the floor, I’ll reconsider this foolish notion” — sure, Ocean and Notion rhyme, but did you catch the assonant rhyme between river and reconsider? 2) If you’re writing after the music is composed, think about syntax and phrasing. Try to get the important words onto the places where the music stresses them. Remember that singing is, in a good measure, acting, and help the actor out by positioning phrases to take advantage of the tones and rhythm of the music. Listen to Sinatra’s “In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning”; it’s a guy who lost a girl feeling bad about it at 3 am or so, and do you hear that every breath he takes is a forced sigh? That was written in the syntax and phrasing; the places where the singer takes a breath and hesitates are there in what the words do with the music. Or listen to any decent Irish band do “The Black Velvet Band” and notice how all the sarcastic words about the guy’s hard luck are on the UNemphasized beats; it’s like he’s muttering under his breath about the whole stupid situation that got him a seven-year-sentence, because the pretty girl he was hitting on turned out to be a pickpocket. 3. Have a few real feelings and see if you can make the song catch them exactly. Too many songs are just commercials for a hot-button phrase (“I Write the Songs,” “That’s the Way I Like It”, “God Bless the USA”), or pulling up the nearest available rhyme (“The moon shines above, we’re falling love” “Your charms, you arms” that kind of thing), or maybe worst of all, leaving everything up to the listener to make sense out of. Since I mentioned “Don’t Think Twice, It’s All Right,” compare that with “Just One of Those Things”, “I Will Always Love You,” and “Mrs. Brown You’ve Got a Lovely Daughter.” All four have narrators trying to stay cool and classy while their hearts break open, but it’s four very different narrators — Dylan’s is bitter but won’t say so directly, Porter’s is flippant and refusing to get sucked in to regret, Parton’s is letting herself feel everything and insisting that her ex-lover know it’s there, and the Herman’s Hermits song is more worried about hurting his ex’s feelings than he is about expressing his own. Precision, precision, precision, what feeling exactly are you capturing? Don’t settle too easily. 4. While we’re at it, can you make your narrator a precise someone? Who’s telling this to whom? “The Streets of Laredo,” Marty Robbins’s “Running Gun”, Elvis’s “In the Ghetto,” Scarface’s “Seen A Man Die,” are all about a man dying too young for something too small, but the narrator is (in order) a casual acquaintance who just met him, the dying man himself, an all-seeing being outside the story, and a deeply understanding witness trying to report the truth. All four have the narrator they do for a reason; have a reason for your narrator too.

The history of human culture is essentially a hall of mirrors -an endless array of stories, themes and ideas, mounted and waiting for you to step up and consider the fascinating ways they each reflect your own distinct & intimate experience of being. All good songs capture either a reflection of broader humanity within which we can find ourselves or a reflection within ourselves wherein we can find a broader humanity. My personal favorite method to find ideas for good lyrics… Look for a story, myth, or legend to which you find yourself joyfully, strangely, or curiously attracted. Find a character, icon, or archetype with which you feel some identification, understanding or relationship. I.e. If you were a mythological character, who might you be? If you were living in an old movie or book, what story is it?Now notice experiences, arcs, or ideas lurking in the weft of your story or archetype that resonate with your own experience or that of a human you can solidly imagine and deeply empathize with.NOTE: For most writers trying this out, I recommend working from the perspective you know best: Your own. This can also be a poetic or archetypal “you” -an exaggerated facet of yourself that you can imagine acting with freedom beyond your typical limitations. Keep in mind, though, that the advantage that abides in “write what you know” is likely a deeper authenticity in your consideration and an infusion of greater Truth into your lyrics.Now re-imagine the story as if your life is simply its reflection through the ages, as if any of your moments could be captured in its allegory, as if it is no less than a legend of you -all the little details and distractions, all the momentary concerns and nagging bullshit blasted away. What remains waiting to be recognized? What remains waiting for a reckoning? This is the substrate of profound poetry and epic lyric.Write your song. Rock your song.Go to Step 1.For a couple of personal examples, I offer… ‘Dirty’ -recorded by my band, Letters From Traffic. Narrated in the first person by the Devil (who is never overtly identified), Dirty reconsiders this character as fundamentally misunderstood -and a little frustrated that humans keep blaming him for their poor behavior and choices.‘Minotaur’ -also recorded by Letters From Traffic and the inspiration for the ‘Icarus Iterations’ album. Narrated by a modern day incarnation of Icarus -then a successive Icarus in the second verse who sees the first one fall on the news. These iterations of Icarus continue to make the same mistake over and over again, flying and falling, dying and being reborn, struggling to find a lesson that will break the cycle. But they keep fundamentally missing that it’s not an issue of flying too high. It’s that some problems cannot be resolved by running away.The Minotaur is in all of us. It is our shadow, those un-integrated parts of Self that we project into the world as the prime model of monsterhood and villiany because we cannot tolerate the idea that we might have them inside us.

Here, I am referring to lyrics of both songs and poetry to provide a better idea. Expand your vocabulary- read books and other stuff to get used to more and more words and find excellent rhyming for your creation.Do what your heart says- Lyrics of a song/poetry comes right from the heart. Try combining your heart's thoughts along with your expanded vocabulary and reasoning skills.Listen to other songs and poetry- This will provide you an opportunity to get acquainted wuth new words and will clear your “where to use what” kind of confusions. (Try not copying entire lyrics though)Using choicest words- Make sure your lyrics are meaningful and the words you use match the overall idea of your song/poetry. Try avoid using vulgar lyrics if you are going for the first time. They can ruin the overall mood of the song.Remain in sentence length- Try to make all the lines in your creation take equal time to recite. If it is a poetry, you can adjust the recital speed however, in a song, you need to follow the metronome. So, try lengthening your lyrics accordingly. Happy Songwriting… _R°N_

I agree, lyric writing is really hard. The thing to know is that sites like RhymeZone.com and Thesaurus.com are your friends. Writing lyrics is all about expressing your emotion in a way that fits the formula, so sometimes the word that you want to use isn’t actually the best word too use. There’s also a lot of rearranging sentences. One word might not have a lot of rhymes, so you have to reconfigure the sentence to put an easier word at the end. You might have a syllable requirement in order for it to fit within the tune of the song. Maybe a sentence just doesn’t sound right with the movement of the song. Don’t be afraid to make sentences a little bit ridiculous too! I mean, there are some sentences that are grammatically correct that you wouldn’t want to use because they sound weird, but many that would be weird in normal conversation are okay in normal music. The final thing is that, as much as I’m sure you’ve heard it, practice! It doesn’t come easily to a lot of people, but it’s a great emotional outlet and you should keep trying at it. I hope this helps!

Ideas to write lyrics can be so easy or difficult. It depends how your sensitivity to the surrounding. What happened to your life, happy or sad, will be the point you can start from. First, determine the excerpt of your feeling. Choose the deepest feeling as the main idea. Start to imagine the story’s beginning. Second, keep the story line simple. The complicated one will have not-focused end. Not only ambigous, but doesn’t make sense as well. Third, insert your own or other’s experiences to complete the story to make it lively. Don’t feel guilty to write something dramatic in your text, whether it is real or imaginative. Imagine that your (future) song listeners expect some new experiences. Fourth, make sure that you rely on certain story ending and the text not to long. Brief song is more likely easier to remember.

Have you ever, or do you sometimes, write poetry? If so you have a leg up. Usually, in my experience, lyrics ought not (in most cases) be detailed and overly specific. Lyrics which are really a type of poetry, evoke a mood. Once that is accomplished, you try to free your mind of the minutiae and concrete facts and/or conditions of the song’s tale or story. Listen to some great songwriters, their songs. For instance, Townes Van Zandt, Leonard Cohen, Bruce Springsteen, Bill Morrissey, John Prine, Dylan or course, Joni Mitchell, Baez, Judy Collins, and so, so many. To paraphrase Emily Dickinson, “tell the truth but tell it slant”. Well, actually that is a direct quote. Her advice on writing poetry. Hope this helps a bit. Ron
